column2: Job Trotter, abating nothing of his speed, ran up Holborn, sometimes in the middle of the road, sometimes on the pavement, sometimes in the gutter, as the chances of getting along varied with the press of men, women, children, and coaches, in each division of the thoroughfare, and, regardless of all obstacles stopped not for an instant until he reached the gate of Gray's Inn.
column3: Job Trotter, abating nothing of his speed, ran up Holborn, sometimes in the middle of the road, sometimes on the pavement, sometimes in the gutter, as the chances of getting along varied with the press of men, women, children, and coaches, in each division of the thoroughfare, and, regardless of all obstacles stopped not for an instant until he reached the gate of Gray's Inn.

column2: Notwithstanding all the expedition he had used, however, the gate had been closed a good half-hour when he reached it, and by the time he had discovered Mr. Perker's laundress, who lived with a married daughter, who had bestowed her hand upon a non-resident waiter, who occupied the one-pair of some number in some street closely adjoining to some brewery somewhere behind Gray's Inn Lane, it was within fifteen minutes of closing the prison for the night.
column3: Notwithstanding all the expedition he had used, however, the gate had been closed a good half hour when he reached it, and by the time he had discovered mr Perker's laundress, who lived with a married daughter, who had bestowed her hand upon a non resident waiter, who occupied the one pair of some number in some street closely adjoining to some brewery somewhere behind Gray's Inn Lane, it was within fifteen minutes of closing the prison for the night.

column2: Mr. Lowten had still to be ferreted out from the back parlour of the Magpie and Stump; and Job had scarcely accomplished this object, and communicated Sam Weller's message, when the clock struck ten.
column3: mr Lowten had still to be ferreted out from the back parlour of the Magpie and Stump; and Job had scarcely accomplished this object, and communicated Sam Weller's message, when the clock struck ten.

column2: 'There,' said Lowten, 'it's too late now.
column3: 'There,' said Lowten, 'it's too late now.

column2: You can't get in to-night; you've got the key of the street, my friend.'
column3: You can't get in to night; you've got the key of the street, my friend.'

column2: 'Never mind me,' replied Job.
column3: 'Never mind me,' replied Job.

column2: 'I can sleep anywhere.
column3: 'I can sleep anywhere.

column2: But won't it be better to see Mr. Perker to-night, so that we may be there, the first thing in the morning?'
column3: But won't it be better to see mr Perker to night, so that we may be there, the first thing in the morning?'

column2: 'Why,' responded Lowten, after a little consideration, 'if it was in anybody else's case, Perker wouldn't be best pleased at my going up to his house; but as it's Mr. Pickwick's, I think I may venture to take a cab and charge it to the office.' Deciding on this line of conduct, Mr. Lowten took up his hat, and begging the assembled company to appoint a deputy-chairman during his temporary absence, led the way to the nearest coach-stand.
column3: 'Why,' responded Lowten, after a little consideration, 'if it was in anybody else's case, Perker wouldn't be best pleased at my going up to his house; but as it's mr Pickwick's, I think I may venture to take a cab and charge it to the office.' Deciding on this line of conduct, mr Lowten took up his hat, and begging the assembled company to appoint a deputy chairman during his temporary absence, led the way to the nearest coach stand.

column2: Summoning the cab of most promising appearance, he directed the driver to repair to Montague Place, Russell Square.
column3: Summoning the cab of most promising appearance, he directed the driver to repair to Montague Place, Russell Square.

column2: Mr. Perker had had a dinner-party that day, as was testified by the appearance of lights in the drawing-room windows, the sound of an improved grand piano, and an improvable cabinet voice issuing therefrom, and a rather overpowering smell of meat which pervaded the steps and entry.
column3: mr Perker had had a dinner party that day, as was testified by the appearance of lights in the drawing room windows, the sound of an improved grand piano, and an improvable cabinet voice issuing therefrom, and a rather overpowering smell of meat which pervaded the steps and entry.

column2: In fact, a couple of very good country agencies happening to come up to town, at the same time, an agreeable little party had been got together to meet them, comprising Mr. Snicks, the Life Office Secretary, Mr. Prosee, the eminent counsel, three solicitors, one commissioner of bankrupts, a special pleader from the Temple, a small-eyed peremptory young gentleman, his pupil, who had written a lively book about the law of demises, with a vast quantity of marginal notes and references; and several other eminent and distinguished personages.
column3: In fact, a couple of very good country agencies happening to come up to town, at the same time, an agreeable little party had been got together to meet them, comprising mr Snicks, the Life Office Secretary, mr Prosee, the eminent counsel, three solicitors, one commissioner of bankrupts, a special pleader from the Temple, a small eyed peremptory young gentleman, his pupil, who had written a lively book about the law of demises, with a vast quantity of marginal notes and references; and several other eminent and distinguished personages.

column2: From this society, little Mr. Perker detached himself, on his clerk being announced in a whisper; and repairing to the dining-room, there found Mr. Lowten and Job Trotter looking very dim and shadowy by the light of a kitchen candle, which the gentleman who condescended to appear in plush shorts and cottons for a quarterly stipend, had, with a becoming contempt for the clerk and all things appertaining to 'the office,' placed upon the table.
column3: From this society, little mr Perker detached himself, on his clerk being announced in a whisper; and repairing to the dining room, there found mr Lowten and Job Trotter looking very dim and shadowy by the light of a kitchen candle, which the gentleman who condescended to appear in plush shorts and cottons for a quarterly stipend, had, with a becoming contempt for the clerk and all things appertaining to 'the office,' placed upon the table.

column2: 'Now, Lowten,' said little Mr. Perker, shutting the door,'what's the matter?
column3: 'Now, Lowten,' said little mr Perker, shutting the door,'what's the matter?

column2: No important letter come in a parcel, is there?'
column3: No important letter come in a parcel, is there?'

column3: 'No, Sir,' replied Lowten.

column2: 'This is a messenger from Mr. Pickwick, Sir.'
column3: 'This is a messenger from mr Pickwick, Sir.'

column2: 'From Pickwick, eh?' said the little man, turning quickly to Job. 'Well, what is it?'
column3: 'From Pickwick, eh?' said the little man, turning quickly to Job. 'Well, what is it?'

column2: 'Dodson and Fogg have taken Mrs. Bardell in execution for her costs, Sir,' said Job.
column3: 'Dodson and Fogg have taken mrs Bardell in execution for her costs, Sir,' said Job.

column2: 'No!' exclaimed Perker, putting his hands in his pockets, and reclining against the sideboard.

column3: 'Yes,' said Job. 'It seems they got a cognovit out of her, for the amount of 'em, directly after the trial.'

column2: 'By Jove!' said Perker, taking both hands out of his pockets, and striking the knuckles of his right against the palm of his left, emphatically, 'those are the cleverest scamps I ever had anything to do with!'
column3: 'By Jove!' said Perker, taking both hands out of his pockets, and striking the knuckles of his right against the palm of his left, emphatically, 'those are the cleverest scamps I ever had anything to do with!'

column2: 'The sharpest practitioners I ever knew, Sir,' observed Lowten.

column2: 'Sharp!' echoed Perker. 'There's no knowing where to have them.'
column3: 'Sharp!' echoed Perker. 'There's no knowing where to have them.'

column2: 'Very true, Sir, there is not,' replied Lowten; and then, both master and man pondered for a few seconds, with animated countenances, as if they were reflecting upon one of the most beautiful and ingenious discoveries that the intellect of man had ever made.

column2: When they had in some measure recovered from their trance of admiration, Job Trotter discharged himself of the rest of his commission.

column2: Perker nodded his head thoughtfully, and pulled out his watch.
column3: Perker nodded his head thoughtfully, and pulled out his watch.

column2: 'At ten precisely, I will be there,' said the little man.

column2: 'Sam is quite right.
column3: 'Sam is quite right.

column2: Will you take a glass of wine, Lowten?' 'No, thank you, Sir.'
column3: Will you take a glass of wine, Lowten?' 'No, thank you, Sir.'

column2: 'You mean yes, I think,' said the little man, turning to the sideboard for a decanter and glasses.

column2: As Lowten DID mean yes, he said no more on the subject, but inquired of Job, in an audible whisper, whether the portrait of Perker, which hung opposite the fireplace, wasn't a wonderful likeness, to which Job of course replied that it was.

column2: The wine being by this time poured out, Lowten drank to Mrs. Perker and the children, and Job to Perker.
column3: The wine being by this time poured out, Lowten drank to mrs Perker and the children, and Job to Perker.

column2: The gentleman in the plush shorts and cottons considering it no part of his duty to show the people from the office out, consistently declined to answer the bell, and they showed themselves out.
column3: The gentleman in the plush shorts and cottons considering it no part of his duty to show the people from the office out, consistently declined to answer the bell, and they showed themselves out.

column2: The attorney betook himself to his drawing-room, the clerk to the Magpie and Stump, and Job to Covent Garden Market to spend the night in a vegetable basket.
column3: The attorney betook himself to his drawing room, the clerk to the Magpie and Stump, and Job to Covent Garden Market to spend the night in a vegetable basket.

column2: Punctually at the appointed hour next morning, the good-humoured little attorney tapped at Mr. Pickwick's door, which was opened with great alacrity by Sam Weller.
column3: Punctually at the appointed hour next morning, the good humoured little attorney tapped at mr Pickwick's door, which was opened with great alacrity by Sam Weller.

column2: 'Mr. Perker, sir,' said Sam, announcing the visitor to Mr. Pickwick, who was sitting at the window in a thoughtful attitude.
column3: 'mr Perker, sir,' said Sam, announcing the visitor to mr Pickwick, who was sitting at the window in a thoughtful attitude.

column2: 'Wery glad you've looked in accidentally, Sir.
column3: 'Wery glad you've looked in accidentally, Sir.

column2: I rather think the gov'nor wants to have a word and a half with you, Sir.'
column3: I rather think the gov'nor wants to have a word and a half with you, Sir.'

column2: Perker bestowed a look of intelligence on Sam, intimating that he understood he was not to say he had been sent for; and beckoning him to approach, whispered briefly in his ear.
column3: Perker bestowed a look of intelligence on Sam, intimating that he understood he was not to say he had been sent for; and beckoning him to approach, whispered briefly in his ear.

column2: 'You don't mean that 'ere, Sir?' said Sam, starting back in excessive surprise.
column3: 'You don't mean that 'ere, Sir?' said Sam, starting back in excessive surprise.

column2: Perker nodded and smiled.
column3: Perker nodded and smiled.

column2: Mr. Samuel Weller looked at the little lawyer, then at Mr. Pickwick, then at the ceiling, then at Perker again; grinned, laughed outright, and finally, catching up his hat from the carpet, without further explanation, disappeared.
column3: mr Samuel Weller looked at the little lawyer, then at mr Pickwick, then at the ceiling, then at Perker again; grinned, laughed outright, and finally, catching up his hat from the carpet, without further explanation, disappeared.

column2: 'What does this mean?' inquired Mr. Pickwick, looking at Perker with astonishment.
column3: 'What does this mean?' inquired mr Pickwick, looking at Perker with astonishment.

column2: 'What has put Sam into this extraordinary state?'
column3: 'What has put Sam into this extraordinary state?'

column2: 'Oh, nothing, nothing,' replied Perker. 'Come, my dear Sir, draw up your chair to the table.
column3: 'Oh, nothing, nothing,' replied Perker. 'Come, my dear Sir, draw up your chair to the table.

column2: I have a good deal to say to you.'
column3: I have a good deal to say to you.'

column2: 'What papers are those?' inquired Mr. Pickwick, as the little man deposited on the table a small bundle of documents tied with red tape.
column3: 'What papers are those?' inquired mr Pickwick, as the little man deposited on the table a small bundle of documents tied with red tape.

column2: 'The papers in Bardell and Pickwick,' replied Perker, undoing the knot with his teeth.
column3: 'The papers in Bardell and Pickwick,' replied Perker, undoing the knot with his teeth.

column2: Mr. Pickwick grated the legs of his chair against the ground; and throwing himself into it, folded his hands and looked sternly--if Mr. Pickwick ever could look sternly--at his legal friend.
column3: mr Pickwick grated the legs of his chair against the ground; and throwing himself into it, folded his hands and looked sternly-if mr Pickwick ever could look sternly-at his legal friend.

column2: 'You don't like to hear the name of the cause?' said the little man, still busying himself with the knot.
column3: 'You don't like to hear the name of the cause?' said the little man, still busying himself with the knot.

column2: 'No, I do not indeed,' replied Mr. Pickwick.
column3: 'No, I do not indeed,' replied mr Pickwick.

column2: 'Sorry for that,' resumed Perker, 'because it will form the subject of our conversation.'
column3: 'Sorry for that,' resumed Perker, 'because it will form the subject of our conversation.'

column2: 'I would rather that the subject should be never mentioned between us, Perker,' interposed Mr. Pickwick hastily.
column3: 'I would rather that the subject should be never mentioned between us, Perker,' interposed mr Pickwick hastily.

column2: 'Pooh, pooh, my dear Sir,' said the little man, untying the bundle, and glancing eagerly at Mr. Pickwick out of the corners of his eyes.
column3: 'Pooh, pooh, my dear Sir,' said the little man, untying the bundle, and glancing eagerly at mr Pickwick out of the corners of his eyes.

column2: 'It must be mentioned.
column3: 'It must be mentioned.

column2: I have come here on purpose.
column3: I have come here on purpose.

column2: Now, are you ready to hear what I have to say, my dear Sir?
column3: Now, are you ready to hear what I have to say, my dear Sir?

column2: No hurry; if you are not, I can wait.
column3: No hurry; if you are not, I can wait.

column2: I have this morning's paper here.
column3: I have this morning's paper here.

column2: Your time shall be mine.
column3: Your time shall be mine.

column2: There!' Hereupon, the little man threw one leg over the other, and made a show of beginning to read with great composure and application.
column3: There!' Hereupon, the little man threw one leg over the other, and made a show of beginning to read with great composure and application.

column2: 'Well, well,' said Mr. Pickwick, with a sigh, but softening into a smile at the same time.
column3: 'Well, well,' said mr Pickwick, with a sigh, but softening into a smile at the same time.

column2: 'Say what you have to say; it's the old story, I suppose?'
column3: 'Say what you have to say; it's the old story, I suppose?'

column2: 'With a difference, my dear Sir; with a difference,' rejoined Perker, deliberately folding up the paper and putting it into his pocket again. 'Mrs.

column2: Bardell, the plaintiff in the action, is within these walls, Sir.'
column3: Bardell, the plaintiff in the action, is within these walls, Sir.'

column2: 'I know it,' was Mr. Pickwick's reply.
column3: 'I know it,' was mr Pickwick's reply.

column2: 'Very good,' retorted Perker.
column3: 'Very good,' retorted Perker.

column2: 'And you know how she comes here, I suppose; I mean on what grounds, and at whose suit?'
column3: 'And you know how she comes here, I suppose; I mean on what grounds, and at whose suit?'

column2: 'Yes; at least I have heard Sam's account of the matter,' said Mr. Pickwick, with affected carelessness.
column3: 'Yes; at least I have heard Sam's account of the matter,' said mr Pickwick, with affected carelessness.

column2: 'Sam's account of the matter,' replied Perker, 'is, I will venture to say, a perfectly correct one.
column3: 'Sam's account of the matter,' replied Perker, 'is, I will venture to say, a perfectly correct one.

column2: Well now, my dear Sir, the first question I have to ask, is, whether this woman is to remain here?'
column3: Well now, my dear Sir, the first question I have to ask, is, whether this woman is to remain here?'

column2: 'To remain here!' echoed Mr. Pickwick.
column3: 'To remain here!' echoed mr Pickwick.

column2: 'To remain here, my dear Sir,' rejoined Perker, leaning back in his chair and looking steadily at his client.
column3: 'To remain here, my dear Sir,' rejoined Perker, leaning back in his chair and looking steadily at his client.

column2: 'How can you ask me?' said that gentleman.
column3: 'How can you ask me?' said that gentleman.

column2: 'It rests with Dodson and Fogg; you know that very well.'
column3: 'It rests with Dodson and Fogg; you know that very well.'

column2: 'I know nothing of the kind,' retorted Perker firmly.
column3: 'I know nothing of the kind,' retorted Perker firmly.

column2: 'It does NOT rest with Dodson and Fogg; you know the men, my dear Sir, as well as I do.
column3: 'It does NOT rest with Dodson and Fogg; you know the men, my dear Sir, as well as I do.

column2: It rests solely, wholly, and entirely with you.'
column3: It rests solely, wholly, and entirely with you.'

column2: 'With me!' ejaculated Mr. Pickwick, rising nervously from his chair, and reseating himself directly afterwards.
column3: 'With me!' ejaculated mr Pickwick, rising nervously from his chair, and reseating himself directly afterwards.

column2: The little man gave a double-knock on the lid of his snuff-box, opened it, took a great pinch, shut it up again, and repeated the words, 'With you.'
column3: The little man gave a double knock on the lid of his snuff box, opened it, took a great pinch, shut it up again, and repeated the words, 'With you.'

column2: 'I say, my dear Sir,' resumed the little man, who seemed to gather confidence from the snuff--'I say, that her speedy liberation or perpetual imprisonment rests with you, and with you alone.
column3: 'I say, my dear Sir,' resumed the little man, who seemed to gather confidence from the snuff-'I say, that her speedy liberation or perpetual imprisonment rests with you, and with you alone.

column2: Hear me out, my dear Sir, if you please, and do not be so very energetic, for it will only put you into a perspiration and do no good whatever.
column3: Hear me out, my dear Sir, if you please, and do not be so very energetic, for it will only put you into a perspiration and do no good whatever.

column2: I say,' continued Perker, checking off each position on a different finger, as he laid it down--'I say that nobody but you can rescue her from this den of wretchedness; and that you can only do that, by paying the costs of this suit--both of plaintive and defendant--into the hands of these Freeman Court sharks.
column3: I say,' continued Perker, checking off each position on a different finger, as he laid it down-'I say that nobody but you can rescue her from this den of wretchedness; and that you can only do that, by paying the costs of this suit-both of plaintive and defendant-into the hands of these Freeman Court sharks.

column2: Now pray be quiet, my dear sir.'
column3: Now pray be quiet, my dear sir.'

column2: Mr. Pickwick, whose face had been undergoing most surprising changes during this speech, and was evidently on the verge of a strong burst of indignation, calmed his wrath as well as he could.
column3: mr Pickwick, whose face had been undergoing most surprising changes during this speech, and was evidently on the verge of a strong burst of indignation, calmed his wrath as well as he could.

column2: Perker, strengthening his argumentative powers with another pinch of snuff, proceeded--
column3: Perker, strengthening his argumentative powers with another pinch of snuff, proceeded-

column2: 'I have seen the woman, this morning.
column3: 'I have seen the woman, this morning.

column2: By paying the costs, you can obtain a full release and discharge from the damages; and further--this I know is a far greater object of consideration with you, my dear sir--a voluntary statement, under her hand, in the form of a letter to me, that this business was, from the very first, fomented, and encouraged, and brought about, by these men, Dodson and Fogg; that she deeply regrets ever having been the instrument of annoyance or injury to you; and that she entreats me to intercede with you, and implore your pardon.'
column3: By paying the costs, you can obtain a full release and discharge from the damages; and further-this I know is a far greater object of consideration with you, my dear sir-a voluntary statement, under her hand, in the form of a letter to me, that this business was, from the very first, fomented, and encouraged, and brought about, by these men, Dodson and Fogg; that she deeply regrets ever having been the instrument of annoyance or injury to you; and that she entreats me to intercede with you, and implore your pardon.'

column2: 'If I pay her costs for her,' said Mr. Pickwick indignantly.
column3: 'If I pay her costs for her,' said mr Pickwick indignantly.

column2: 'A valuable document, indeed!'
column3: 'A valuable document, indeed!'

column2: 'No "if" in the case, my dear Sir,' said Perker triumphantly.
column3: 'No "if" in the case, my dear Sir,' said Perker triumphantly.

column2: 'There is the very letter I speak of.
column3: 'There is the very letter I speak of.

column2: Brought to my office by another woman at nine o'clock this morning, before I had set foot in this place, or held any communication with Mrs. Bardell, upon my honour.' Selecting the letter from the bundle, the little lawyer laid it at Mr. Pickwick's elbow, and took snuff for two consecutive minutes, without winking.
column3: Brought to my office by another woman at nine o'clock this morning, before I had set foot in this place, or held any communication with mrs Bardell, upon my honour.' Selecting the letter from the bundle, the little lawyer laid it at mr Pickwick's elbow, and took snuff for two consecutive minutes, without winking.

column2: 'Is this all you have to say to me?' inquired Mr. Pickwick mildly.
column3: 'Is this all you have to say to me?' inquired mr Pickwick mildly.

column2: 'Not quite,' replied Perker.
column3: 'Not quite,' replied Perker.

column2: 'I cannot undertake to say, at this moment, whether the wording of the cognovit, the nature of the ostensible consideration, and the proof we can get together about the whole conduct of the suit, will be sufficient to justify an indictment for conspiracy. I fear not, my dear Sir; they are too clever for that, I doubt.
column3: 'I cannot undertake to say, at this moment, whether the wording of the cognovit, the nature of the ostensible consideration, and the proof we can get together about the whole conduct of the suit, will be sufficient to justify an indictment for conspiracy. I fear not, my dear Sir; they are too clever for that, I doubt.

column2: I do mean to say, however, that the whole facts, taken together, will be sufficient to justify you, in the minds of all reasonable men.
column3: I do mean to say, however, that the whole facts, taken together, will be sufficient to justify you, in the minds of all reasonable men.

column2: And now, my dear Sir, I put it to you.
column3: And now, my dear Sir, I put it to you.

column2: This one hundred and fifty pounds, or whatever it may be--take it in round numbers--is nothing to you.
column3: This one hundred and fifty pounds, or whatever it may be-take it in round numbers-is nothing to you.

column2: A jury had decided against you; well, their verdict is wrong, but still they decided as they thought right, and it IS against you.
column3: A jury had decided against you; well, their verdict is wrong, but still they decided as they thought right, and it IS against you.

column2: You have now an opportunity, on easy terms, of placing yourself in a much higher position than you ever could, by remaining here; which would only be imputed, by people who didn't know you, to sheer dogged, wrongheaded, brutal obstinacy; nothing else, my dear Sir, believe me.
column3: You have now an opportunity, on easy terms, of placing yourself in a much higher position than you ever could, by remaining here; which would only be imputed, by people who didn't know you, to sheer dogged, wrongheaded, brutal obstinacy; nothing else, my dear Sir, believe me.

column2: Can you hesitate to avail yourself of it, when it restores you to your friends, your old pursuits, your health and amusements; when it liberates your faithful and attached servant, whom you otherwise doom to imprisonment for the whole of your life; and above all, when it enables you to take the very magnanimous revenge--which I know, my dear sir, is one after your own heart--of releasing this woman from a scene of misery and debauchery, to which no man should ever be consigned, if I had my will, but the infliction of which on any woman, is even more frightful and barbarous.
column3: Can you hesitate to avail yourself of it, when it restores you to your friends, your old pursuits, your health and amusements; when it liberates your faithful and attached servant, whom you otherwise doom to imprisonment for the whole of your life; and above all, when it enables you to take the very magnanimous revenge-which I know, my dear sir, is one after your own heart-of releasing this woman from a scene of misery and debauchery, to which no man should ever be consigned, if I had my will, but the infliction of which on any woman, is even more frightful and barbarous.

column2: Now I ask you, my dear sir, not only as your legal adviser, but as your very true friend, will you let slip the occasion of attaining all these objects, and doing all this good, for the paltry consideration of a few pounds finding their way into the pockets of a couple of rascals, to whom it makes no manner of difference, except that the more they gain, the more they'll seek, and so the sooner be led into some piece of knavery that must end in a crash?
column3: Now I ask you, my dear sir, not only as your legal adviser, but as your very true friend, will you let slip the occasion of attaining all these objects, and doing all this good, for the paltry consideration of a few pounds finding their way into the pockets of a couple of rascals, to whom it makes no manner of difference, except that the more they gain, the more they'll seek, and so the sooner be led into some piece of knavery that must end in a crash?

column2: I have put these considerations to you, my dear Sir, very feebly and imperfectly, but I ask you to think of them.
column3: I have put these considerations to you, my dear Sir, very feebly and imperfectly, but I ask you to think of them.

column2: Turn them over in your mind as long as you please.
column3: Turn them over in your mind as long as you please.

column2: I wait here most patiently for your answer.'
column3: I wait here most patiently for your answer.'

column2: Before Mr. Pickwick could reply, before Mr. Perker had taken one twentieth part of the snuff with which so unusually long an address imperatively required to be followed up, there was a low murmuring of voices outside, and then a hesitating knock at the door.
column3: Before mr Pickwick could reply, before mr Perker had taken one twentieth part of the snuff with which so unusually long an address imperatively required to be followed up, there was a low murmuring of voices outside, and then a hesitating knock at the door.

column2: 'Dear, dear,' exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, who had been evidently roused by his friend's appeal; 'what an annoyance that door is!
column3: 'Dear, dear,' exclaimed mr Pickwick, who had been evidently roused by his friend's appeal; 'what an annoyance that door is!

column2: Who is that?'
column3: Who is that?'

column2: 'Me, Sir,' replied Sam Weller, putting in his head.
column3: 'Me, Sir,' replied Sam Weller, putting in his head.

column2: 'I can't speak to you just now, Sam,' said Mr. Pickwick. 'I am engaged at this moment, Sam.'
column3: 'I can't speak to you just now, Sam,' said mr Pickwick. 'I am engaged at this moment, Sam.'

column2: 'Beg your pardon, Sir,' rejoined Mr. Weller. 'But here's a lady here, Sir, as says she's somethin' wery partickler to disclose.'
column3: 'Beg your pardon, Sir,' rejoined mr Weller. 'But here's a lady here, Sir, as says she's somethin' wery partickler to disclose.'

column2: 'I can't see any lady,' replied Mr. Pickwick, whose mind was filled with visions of Mrs. Bardell.
column3: 'I can't see any lady,' replied mr Pickwick, whose mind was filled with visions of mrs Bardell.

column2: 'I wouldn't make too sure o' that, Sir,' urged Mr. Weller, shaking his head.
column3: 'I wouldn't make too sure o' that, Sir,' urged mr Weller, shaking his head.

column2: 'If you know'd who was near, sir, I rayther think you'd change your note; as the hawk remarked to himself vith a cheerful laugh, ven he heerd the robin-redbreast a-singin' round the corner.'
column3: 'If you know'd who was near, sir, I rayther think you'd change your note; as the hawk remarked to himself vith a cheerful laugh, ven he heerd the robin redbreast a singin' round the corner.'

column2: 'Who is it?' inquired Mr. Pickwick.
column3: 'Who is it?' inquired mr Pickwick.

column2: 'Will you see her, Sir?' asked Mr. Weller, holding the door in his hand as if he had some curious live animal on the other side.
column3: 'Will you see her, Sir?' asked mr Weller, holding the door in his hand as if he had some curious live animal on the other side.

column2: 'I suppose I must,' said Mr. Pickwick, looking at Perker.
column3: 'I suppose I must,' said mr Pickwick, looking at Perker.

column2: 'Well then, all in to begin!' cried Sam. 'Sound the gong, draw up the curtain, and enter the two conspiraytors.'
column3: 'Well then, all in to begin!' cried Sam. 'Sound the gong, draw up the curtain, and enter the two conspiraytors.'

column2: As Sam Weller spoke, he threw the door open, and there rushed tumultuously into the room, Mr. Nathaniel Winkle, leading after him by the hand, the identical young lady who at Dingley Dell had worn the boots with the fur round the tops, and who, now a very pleasing compound of blushes and confusion, and lilac silk, and a smart bonnet, and a rich lace veil, looked prettier than ever.
column3: As Sam Weller spoke, he threw the door open, and there rushed tumultuously into the room, mr Nathaniel Winkle, leading after him by the hand, the identical young lady who at Dingley Dell had worn the boots with the fur round the tops, and who, now a very pleasing compound of blushes and confusion, and lilac silk, and a smart bonnet, and a rich lace veil, looked prettier than ever.

column2: 'Miss Arabella Allen!' exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, rising from his chair.
column3: 'Miss Arabella Allen!' exclaimed mr Pickwick, rising from his chair.

column2: 'No,' replied Mr. Winkle, dropping on his knees.
column3: 'No,' replied mr Winkle, dropping on his knees.

column2: 'Mrs.
column3: 'mrs

column2: Winkle.
column3: Winkle.

column2: Pardon, my dear friend, pardon!'
column3: Pardon, my dear friend, pardon!'

column2: Mr. Pickwick could scarcely believe the evidence of his senses, and perhaps would not have done so, but for the corroborative testimony afforded by the smiling countenance of Perker, and the bodily presence, in the background, of Sam and the pretty housemaid; who appeared to contemplate the proceedings with the liveliest satisfaction.
column3: mr Pickwick could scarcely believe the evidence of his senses, and perhaps would not have done so, but for the corroborative testimony afforded by the smiling countenance of Perker, and the bodily presence, in the background, of Sam and the pretty housemaid; who appeared to contemplate the proceedings with the liveliest satisfaction.

column2: 'Oh, Mr. Pickwick!' said Arabella, in a low voice, as if alarmed at the silence.
column3: 'Oh, mr Pickwick!' said Arabella, in a low voice, as if alarmed at the silence.

column2: 'Can you forgive my imprudence?'
column3: 'Can you forgive my imprudence?'

column2: Mr. Pickwick returned no verbal response to this appeal; but he took off his spectacles in great haste, and seizing both the young lady's hands in his, kissed her a great number of times--perhaps a greater number than was absolutely necessary--and then, still retaining one of her hands, told Mr. Winkle he was an audacious young dog, and bade him get up.
column3: mr Pickwick returned no verbal response to this appeal; but he took off his spectacles in great haste, and seizing both the young lady's hands in his, kissed her a great number of times-perhaps a greater number than was absolutely necessary-and then, still retaining one of her hands, told mr Winkle he was an audacious young dog, and bade him get up.

column2: This, Mr. Winkle, who had been for some seconds scratching his nose with the brim of his hat, in a penitent manner, did; whereupon Mr. Pickwick slapped him on the back several times, and then shook hands heartily with Perker, who, not to be behind-hand in the compliments of the occasion, saluted both the bride and the pretty housemaid with right good-will, and, having wrung Mr. Winkle's hand most cordially, wound up his demonstrations of joy by taking snuff enough to set any half-dozen men with ordinarily-constructed noses, a-sneezing for life.
column3: This, mr Winkle, who had been for some seconds scratching his nose with the brim of his hat, in a penitent manner, did; whereupon mr Pickwick slapped him on the back several times, and then shook hands heartily with Perker, who, not to be behind hand in the compliments of the occasion, saluted both the bride and the pretty housemaid with right good will, and, having wrung mr Winkle's hand most cordially, wound up his demonstrations of joy by taking snuff enough to set any half dozen men with ordinarily constructed noses, a sneezing for life.

column2: 'Why, my dear girl,' said Mr. Pickwick, 'how has all this come about?
column3: 'Why, my dear girl,' said mr Pickwick, 'how has all this come about?

column2: Come!
column3: Come!

column2: Sit down, and let me hear it all.
column3: Sit down, and let me hear it all.

column2: How well she looks, doesn't she, Perker?' added Mr. Pickwick, surveying Arabella's face with a look of as much pride and exultation, as if she had been his daughter.
column3: How well she looks, doesn't she, Perker?' added mr Pickwick, surveying Arabella's face with a look of as much pride and exultation, as if she had been his daughter.

column2: 'Delightful, my dear Sir,' replied the little man.
column3: 'Delightful, my dear Sir,' replied the little man.

column2: 'If I were not a married man myself, I should be disposed to envy you, you dog.' Thus expressing himself, the little lawyer gave Mr. Winkle a poke in the chest, which that gentleman reciprocated; after which they both laughed very loudly, but not so loudly as Mr. Samuel Weller, who had just relieved his feelings by kissing the pretty housemaid under cover of the cupboard door.
column3: 'If I were not a married man myself, I should be disposed to envy you, you dog.' Thus expressing himself, the little lawyer gave mr Winkle a poke in the chest, which that gentleman reciprocated; after which they both laughed very loudly, but not so loudly as mr Samuel Weller, who had just relieved his feelings by kissing the pretty housemaid under cover of the cupboard door.

column2: 'I can never be grateful enough to you, Sam, I am sure,' said Arabella, with the sweetest smile imaginable.
column3: 'I can never be grateful enough to you, Sam, I am sure,' said Arabella, with the sweetest smile imaginable.

column2: 'I shall not forget your exertions in the garden at Clifton.'
column3: 'I shall not forget your exertions in the garden at Clifton.'

column2: 'Don't say nothin' wotever about it, ma'am,' replied Sam. 'I only assisted natur, ma'am; as the doctor said to the boy's mother, after he'd bled him to death.'
column3: 'Don't say nothin' wotever about it, ma'am,' replied Sam. 'I only assisted natur, ma'am; as the doctor said to the boy's mother, after he'd bled him to death.'

column2: 'Mary, my dear, sit down,' said Mr. Pickwick, cutting short these compliments.
column3: 'Mary, my dear, sit down,' said mr Pickwick, cutting short these compliments.

column2: 'Now then; how long have you been married, eh?'
column3: 'Now then; how long have you been married, eh?'

column2: Arabella looked bashfully at her lord and master, who replied, 'Only three days.'
column3: Arabella looked bashfully at her lord and master, who replied, 'Only three days.'

column2: 'Only three days, eh?' said Mr. Pickwick. 'Why, what have you been doing these three months?'
column3: 'Only three days, eh?' said mr Pickwick. 'Why, what have you been doing these three months?'

column2: 'Ah, to be sure!' interposed Perker; 'come, account for this idleness. You see Mr. Pickwick's only astonishment is, that it wasn't all over, months ago.'
column3: 'Ah, to be sure!' interposed Perker; 'come, account for this idleness. You see mr Pickwick's only astonishment is, that it wasn't all over, months ago.'

column2: 'Why the fact is,' replied Mr. Winkle, looking at his blushing young wife, 'that I could not persuade Bella to run away, for a long time.
column3: 'Why the fact is,' replied mr Winkle, looking at his blushing young wife, 'that I could not persuade Bella to run away, for a long time.

column2: And when I had persuaded her, it was a long time more before we could find an opportunity.
column3: And when I had persuaded her, it was a long time more before we could find an opportunity.

column2: Mary had to give a month's warning, too, before she could leave her place next door, and we couldn't possibly have done it without her assistance.' 'Upon my word,' exclaimed Mr. Pickwick, who by this time had resumed his spectacles, and was looking from Arabella to Winkle, and from Winkle to Arabella, with as much delight depicted in his countenance as warmheartedness and kindly feeling can communicate to the human face--'upon my word! you seem to have been very systematic in your proceedings.
column3: Mary had to give a month's warning, too, before she could leave her place next door, and we couldn't possibly have done it without her assistance.' 'Upon my word,' exclaimed mr Pickwick, who by this time had resumed his spectacles, and was looking from Arabella to Winkle, and from Winkle to Arabella, with as much delight depicted in his countenance as warmheartedness and kindly feeling can communicate to the human face-'upon my word! you seem to have been very systematic in your proceedings.

column2: And is your brother acquainted with all this, my dear?'
column3: And is your brother acquainted with all this, my dear?'

column2: 'Oh, no, no,' replied Arabella, changing colour.
column3: 'Oh, no, no,' replied Arabella, changing colour.

column2: 'Dear Mr. Pickwick, he must only know it from you--from your lips alone.
column3: 'Dear mr Pickwick, he must only know it from you-from your lips alone.

column2: He is so violent, so prejudiced, and has been so--so anxious in behalf of his friend, Mr. Sawyer,' added Arabella, looking down, 'that I fear the consequences dreadfully.'
column3: He is so violent, so prejudiced, and has been so-so anxious in behalf of his friend, mr Sawyer,' added Arabella, looking down, 'that I fear the consequences dreadfully.'

column2: 'Ah, to be sure,' said Perker gravely.
column3: 'Ah, to be sure,' said Perker gravely.

column2: 'You must take this matter in hand for them, my dear sir.
column3: 'You must take this matter in hand for them, my dear sir.

column2: These young men will respect you, when they would listen to nobody else.
column3: These young men will respect you, when they would listen to nobody else.

column2: You must prevent mischief, my dear Sir.
column3: You must prevent mischief, my dear Sir.

column2: Hot blood, hot blood.' And the little man took a warning pinch, and shook his head doubtfully.
column3: Hot blood, hot blood.' And the little man took a warning pinch, and shook his head doubtfully.

column2: 'You forget, my love,' said Mr. Pickwick gently, 'you forget that I am a prisoner.'
column3: 'You forget, my love,' said mr Pickwick gently, 'you forget that I am a prisoner.'

column2: 'No, indeed I do not, my dear Sir,' replied Arabella. 'I never have forgotten it.
column3: 'No, indeed I do not, my dear Sir,' replied Arabella. 'I never have forgotten it.

column2: I have never ceased to think how great your sufferings must have been in this shocking place.
column3: I have never ceased to think how great your sufferings must have been in this shocking place.

column2: But I hoped that what no consideration for yourself would induce you to do, a regard to our happiness might.
column3: But I hoped that what no consideration for yourself would induce you to do, a regard to our happiness might.

column2: If my brother hears of this, first, from you, I feel certain we shall be reconciled.
column3: If my brother hears of this, first, from you, I feel certain we shall be reconciled.

column2: He is my only relation in the world, Mr. Pickwick, and unless you plead for me, I fear I have lost even him.
column3: He is my only relation in the world, mr Pickwick, and unless you plead for me, I fear I have lost even him.

column2: I have done wrong, very, very wrong, I know.'Here poor Arabella hid her face in her handkerchief, and wept bitterly.
column3: I have done wrong, very, very wrong, I know.'Here poor Arabella hid her face in her handkerchief, and wept bitterly.

column2: Mr. Pickwick's nature was a good deal worked upon, by these same tears; but when Mrs. Winkle, drying her eyes, took to coaxing and entreating in the sweetest tones of a very sweet voice, he became particularly restless, and evidently undecided how to act, as was evinced by sundry nervous rubbings of his spectacle-glasses, nose, tights, head, and gaiters.
column3: mr Pickwick's nature was a good deal worked upon, by these same tears; but when mrs Winkle, drying her eyes, took to coaxing and entreating in the sweetest tones of a very sweet voice, he became particularly restless, and evidently undecided how to act, as was evinced by sundry nervous rubbings of his spectacle glasses, nose, tights, head, and gaiters.

column2: Taking advantage of these symptoms of indecision, Mr. Perker (to whom, it appeared, the young couple had driven straight that morning) urged with legal point and shrewdness that Mr. Winkle, senior, was still unacquainted with the important rise in life's flight of steps which his son had taken; that the future expectations of the said son depended entirely upon the said Winkle, senior, continuing to regard him with undiminished feelings of affection and attachment, which it was very unlikely he would, if this great event were long kept a secret from him; that Mr. Pickwick, repairing to Bristol to seek Mr. Allen, might, with equal reason, repair to Birmingham to seek Mr. Winkle, senior; lastly, that Mr. Winkle, senior, had good right and title to consider Mr. Pickwick as in some degree the guardian and adviser of his son, and that it consequently behoved that gentleman, and was indeed due to his personal character, to acquaint the aforesaid Winkle, senior, personally, and by word of mouth, with the whole circumstances of the case, and with the share he had taken in the transaction.
column3: Taking advantage of these symptoms of indecision, mr Perker (to whom, it appeared, the young couple had driven straight that morning) urged with legal point and shrewdness that mr Winkle, senior, was still unacquainted with the important rise in life's flight of steps which his son had taken; that the future expectations of the said son depended entirely upon the said Winkle, senior, continuing to regard him with undiminished feelings of affection and attachment, which it was very unlikely he would, if this great event were long kept a secret from him; that mr Pickwick, repairing to Bristol to seek mr Allen, might, with equal reason, repair to Birmingham to seek mr Winkle, senior; lastly, that mr Winkle, senior, had good right and title to consider mr Pickwick as in some degree the guardian and adviser of his son, and that it consequently behoved that gentleman, and was indeed due to his personal character, to acquaint the aforesaid Winkle, senior, personally, and by word of mouth, with the whole circumstances of the case, and with the share he had taken in the transaction.

column2: Mr. Tupman and Mr. Snodgrass arrived, most opportunely, in this stage of the pleadings, and as it was necessary to explain to them all that had occurred, together with the various reasons pro and con, the whole of the arguments were gone over again, after which everybody urged every argument in his own way, and at his own length.
column3: mr Tupman and mr Snodgrass arrived, most opportunely, in this stage of the pleadings, and as it was necessary to explain to them all that had occurred, together with the various reasons pro and con, the whole of the arguments were gone over again, after which everybody urged every argument in his own way, and at his own length.

column2: And, at last, Mr. Pickwick, fairly argued and remonstrated out of all his resolutions, and being in imminent danger of being argued and remonstrated out of his wits, caught Arabella in his arms, and declaring that she was a very amiable creature, and that he didn't know how it was, but he had always been very fond of her from the first, said he could never find it in his heart to stand in the way of young people's happiness, and they might do with him as they pleased.
column3: And, at last, mr Pickwick, fairly argued and remonstrated out of all his resolutions, and being in imminent danger of being argued and remonstrated out of his wits, caught Arabella in his arms, and declaring that she was a very amiable creature, and that he didn't know how it was, but he had always been very fond of her from the first, said he could never find it in his heart to stand in the way of young people's happiness, and they might do with him as they pleased.

column2: Mr. Weller's first act, on hearing this concession, was to despatch Job Trotter to the illustrious Mr. Pell, with an authority to deliver to the bearer the formal discharge which his prudent parent had had the foresight to leave in the hands of that learned gentleman, in case it should be, at any time, required on an emergency; his next proceeding was, to invest his whole stock of ready-money in the purchase of five-and-twenty gallons of mild porter, which he himself dispensed on the racket-ground to everybody who would partake of it; this done, he hurra'd in divers parts of the building until he lost his voice, and then quietly relapsed into his usual collected and philosophical condition.
column3: mr Weller's first act, on hearing this concession, was to despatch Job Trotter to the illustrious mr Pell, with an authority to deliver to the bearer the formal discharge which his prudent parent had had the foresight to leave in the hands of that learned gentleman, in case it should be, at any time, required on an emergency; his next proceeding was, to invest his whole stock of ready money in the purchase of five and twenty gallons of mild porter, which he himself dispensed on the racket ground to everybody who would partake of it; this done, he hurra'd in divers parts of the building until he lost his voice, and then quietly relapsed into his usual collected and philosophical condition.

column2: At three o'clock that afternoon, Mr. Pickwick took a last look at his little room, and made his way, as well as he could, through the throng of debtors who pressed eagerly forward to shake him by the hand, until he reached the lodge steps.
column3: At three o'clock that afternoon, mr Pickwick took a last look at his little room, and made his way, as well as he could, through the throng of debtors who pressed eagerly forward to shake him by the hand, until he reached the lodge steps.

column2: He turned here, to look about him, and his eye lightened as he did so.
column3: He turned here, to look about him, and his eye lightened as he did so.

column2: In all the crowd of wan, emaciated faces, he saw not one which was not happier for his sympathy and charity.
column3: In all the crowd of wan, emaciated faces, he saw not one which was not happier for his sympathy and charity.

column2: 'Perker,' said Mr. Pickwick, beckoning one young man towards him, 'this is Mr. Jingle, whom I spoke to you about.'
column3: 'Perker,' said mr Pickwick, beckoning one young man towards him, 'this is mr Jingle, whom I spoke to you about.'

column2: 'Very good, my dear Sir,' replied Perker, looking hard at Jingle. 'You will see me again, young man, to-morrow.
column3: 'Very good, my dear Sir,' replied Perker, looking hard at Jingle. 'You will see me again, young man, to morrow.

column2: I hope you may live to remember and feel deeply, what I shall have to communicate, Sir.'
column3: I hope you may live to remember and feel deeply, what I shall have to communicate, Sir.'

column2: Jingle bowed respectfully, trembled very much as he took Mr. Pickwick's proffered hand, and withdrew.
column3: Jingle bowed respectfully, trembled very much as he took mr Pickwick's proffered hand, and withdrew.

column2: 'Job you know, I think?' said Mr. Pickwick, presenting that gentleman.
column3: 'Job you know, I think?' said mr Pickwick, presenting that gentleman.

column2: 'I know the rascal,' replied Perker good-humouredly.
column3: 'I know the rascal,' replied Perker good humouredly.

column2: 'See after your friend, and be in the way to-morrow at one.
column3: 'See after your friend, and be in the way to morrow at one.

column2: Do you hear?
column3: Do you hear?

column2: Now, is there anything more?'
column3: Now, is there anything more?'

column2: 'Nothing,' rejoined Mr. Pickwick.
column3: 'Nothing,' rejoined mr Pickwick.

column2: 'You have delivered the little parcel I gave you for your old landlord, Sam?'
column3: 'You have delivered the little parcel I gave you for your old landlord, Sam?'

column2: 'I have, Sir,' replied Sam.
column3: 'I have, Sir,' replied Sam.

column2: 'He bust out a-cryin', Sir, and said you wos wery gen'rous and thoughtful, and he only wished you could have him innockilated for a gallopin' consumption, for his old friend as had lived here so long wos dead, and he'd noweres to look for another.' 'Poor fellow, poor fellow!' said Mr. Pickwick. 'God bless you, my friends!'
column3: 'He bust out a cryin', Sir, and said you wos wery gen'rous and thoughtful, and he only wished you could have him innockilated for a gallopin' consumption, for his old friend as had lived here so long wos dead, and he'd noweres to look for another.' 'Poor fellow, poor fellow!' said mr Pickwick. 'God bless you, my friends!'

column2: As Mr. Pickwick uttered this adieu, the crowd raised a loud shout.
column3: As mr Pickwick uttered this adieu, the crowd raised a loud shout.

column2: Many among them were pressing forward to shake him by the hand again, when he drew his arm through Perker's, and hurried from the prison, far more sad and melancholy, for the moment, than when he had first entered it.
column3: Many among them were pressing forward to shake him by the hand again, when he drew his arm through Perker's, and hurried from the prison, far more sad and melancholy, for the moment, than when he had first entered it.

column2: Alas! how many sad and unhappy beings had he left behind!
column3: Alas! how many sad and unhappy beings had he left behind!

column2: A happy evening was that for at least one party in the George and Vulture; and light and cheerful were two of the hearts that emerged from its hospitable door next morning.
column3: A happy evening was that for at least one party in the George and Vulture; and light and cheerful were two of the hearts that emerged from its hospitable door next morning.

column2: The owners thereof were Mr. Pickwick and Sam Weller, the former of whom was speedily deposited inside a comfortable post-coach, with a little dickey behind, in which the latter mounted with great agility.
column3: The owners thereof were mr Pickwick and Sam Weller, the former of whom was speedily deposited inside a comfortable post coach, with a little dickey behind, in which the latter mounted with great agility.

column2: 'Sir,' called out Mr. Weller to his master.
column3: 'Sir,' called out mr Weller to his master.

column2: 'Well, Sam,' replied Mr. Pickwick, thrusting his head out of the window.
column3: 'Well, Sam,' replied mr Pickwick, thrusting his head out of the window.
